entry.title: 2018 Awards
entry.content:
version audio

Avant de commencer 2019, je fais mon bilan personnel de l‚Äòann√©e pass√©e dans divers domaines artistiques. Vu le nombre de tr√®s bonnes s√©ries TV, le calendrier de sorties JV, etc, inutile de pr√©ciser que cette liste est partiale.
L‚Äòann√©e 2018 √©tait ultra-violette, ma couleur pr√©f√©r√©e, voyons si j‚Äôai √©t√© g√¢t√© dans mes tops.

Cinema

üèÜ Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
Je suis sorti la george serr√©e de la s√©ance, submerg√© par l‚Äô√©motion subtilement √©grain√©e par le film mais surtout par la puissance visuelle maintenue tout au long de ces 2 heures et par l‚Äôhommage √† des d√©cennies de comics.

Mentions

  • A Quiet place
    Enfin un bon film de genre high-concept. Une exp√©rience inhabituelle en cin√©ma.
  • Annihilation
    Encore une exp√©rience marquante de l‚Äôann√©e, la sc√®ne de fin avec l'inconnu m‚Äôa glac√© comme rarement.
  • Roma
  • Lawrence of Arabia et 2001: A Space Odyssey en 70mm √† EYE Film (Amsterdam), c‚Äòest grandiose.

Mon top sur SensCritique

Film trailer

üèÜ POK√âMON Detective Pikachu
Bon, √ßa pourrait √™tre pour la blague mais la bande-annonce est sinc√®rement bizarre et, surtout, sortie de (presque) nulle part.

Mentions

  • VICE
    Je d√©teste The Big Short, mais Bush jou√© par Sam Rockwell et Dick Cheney par Christian Bale fonctionnent tellement bien, en tout cas, dans la B-A.

  • Avengers End Game
    ‚ÄúPart of the journey is the end‚Äù

TV


üèÜ Vermin
Diffus√©e sur Blackpills, cette s√©rie devrait √™tre plus connue. Direction artistique impeccable et doublage hilarant, mention sp√©ciale au personnage du commissaire par Ga√´l Mectoob.

Mentions

  • Wild Wild Country
    Pas fan des ‚Äúhistoires vraies‚Äù mais cette s√©rie documentaire est fictionnelle, ce n‚Äôest pas possible autrement !
  • Maniac
  • Homecoming
  • The good place
    Il me tarde de regarder la saison 3 de ma s√©rie SF actuelle pr√©f√©r√©e
  • Final Space
    L'humour lourdingue du perso principal g√¢che un peu la f√™te mais √ßa fait super plaisir de voir une s√©rie d'animation Space opera, vous en connaissez d‚Äôautres vous ?
  • Leftovers
    J'ai un an de retard pour la derni√®re saison, mais cette s√©rie est exceptionnelle. La musique, seule, me fout les frissons.

Mon top sur SensCritique

Music video


üèÜ Dolly.Zero - Antoine Debarge - Ugo Bienvenu
Coup de c≈ìur d√©couvert au KLIK Amsterdam Animation Festival, je vais suivre Ugo Bienvenu avec grand attention.

Mentions

  • This is america - Childish Gambino - Hiro Murai
    Notes: la performance live au SNL m'a fait d√©couvrir cette technique folle de Future Weapons qui synchronise les lasers avec le framerate de la cam√©ra.
  • Free Yourself - The Chemical Brothers
  • POP/STARS - K/DA - Fortiche Prod
    La chanson est oubliable, bien que catchy, mais la r√©alisation par le studio parisien FORTICHE est de tr√®s haut niveau. Eh oui, League of Legends cr√©e des pop stars.
  • Mr. FEAR - SIAM√âS
  • My Way - BVG
  • Les passantes - Georges Brassens - Charlotte Abramow

Music live

üèÜ The Chemicals Brothers
Un show plein de surprises et de bons titres, les mecs sont bons, forc√©ment, √ßa aide.

Mentions

  • Silent Alarm - Bloc Party
  • datamatics [ver.2.0] - Ryoji Ikeda
  • Alt-J
    Vu au Bostheater, un th√©atre en plein air, au milieu de la foret d‚ÄôAmsterdam, je recommande le lieu et le groupe.

Music

Difficile de faire un top quand j‚Äôai majoritairement √©cout√© d‚Äôanciennes chansons dont mes deux chouchous : la d√©couverte d‚ÄôOperator Please (Gloves, Yes Yes Vindictive) et Lastman (Original Series Soundtrack) par Avril & Monthaye

Mentions

  • Francis Trouble - Albert Hammond Jr.
    Je me suis senti tellement honteux par le manque d‚Äôengouement du public les deux fois o√π il a jou√© √† Amsterdam cette ann√©e. Encore meilleur que ces pr√©c√©dents albums.
  • Marble Skies et Winter‚Äôs Beach - Django Django
    Aussi vu deux fois en live cette ann√©e, d√©cidement, dont une fois au Razzmatazz √† Barcelone. Imaginez le rideau qui tombe sur la sc√®ne d‚Äôun club √† 1¬†h du mat alors que le DJ jou√© 10 secondes plus t√¥t, c‚Äô√©tait surr√©aliste.
  • Lavender by Half Waif
  • First Man (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) - Justin Hurwitz

Mon profil Last.fm

Video game trailer

üèÜ Cyberpunk 2077 (E3)
Meilleure bagnole de l‚Äôann√©e. Bonne bande-son, parti pris original de l‚Äôunivers cyberpunk. Et cette voiture, mon dieu !

Mentions

  • Tous Death Stranding

üèÜ Super Smash Bros. Ultimate

Mentions

    que je d√©couvre en ce moment donc j'esp√®re encore √™tre surpris.

La s√©rie est √©trangement amusante m√™me si j‚Äôaurai du mal √† la recommander. Mais il suffit de me passer du France Gall sauce japonaise en g√©n√©rique de fin et j‚Äôai envie de twister.

Podcast

Mentions

Tellement de bons podcasts √† mentionner, mais peu de nouveaut√©s cette ann√©e dans ma liste d‚Äôabonnements et toujours aucun en langue anglaise :

entry.title: Videogames at V&A
entry.content:
version audio

Quelle sera la nation qui ouvrira le premier grand mus√©e du jeu vid√©o ?

En attendant, la Grande-Bretagne est plut√¥t active : Videogames: Design/Play/Disrupt est la derni√®re d‚Äôune courte liste d‚Äôexpositions majeures sur le jeu.

Videogames √©tait organis√©e du 8 septembre 2018 au 24 f√©vrier 2019 dans le magnifique et immense mus√©e Victoria & Albert.
Le V&A a √©t√© fond√© en 1852 en tant que Mus√©e des manufactures apr√®s l‚ÄôExposition universelle de 1851, sp√©cialis√© dans l‚Äôart et le design, il √©tait le lieu parfait pour monter ce projet.
L‚Äôexposition va d‚Äôailleurs continuer son existence dans l‚Äôantenne √©cossaise du V&A.

L‚Äôexposition s‚Äôouvrait sur une citation de Frank Lantz :

‚ÄúMaking games combines everything that‚Äôs hard about building a bridge with everything that‚Äôs hard about composing an opera. Games are basically operas made out of bridges.‚Äù

Le but du projet √©tait donc bien de pr√©senter les structures qui soutiennent la cr√©ation d‚Äôun jeu vid√©o √† un public plut√¥t n√©ophyte.

Design

La premi√®re partie consistait √† mettre √† nu la conception d‚Äôun jeu, √† travers plusieurs ≈ìuvres :

  • L‚Äô√©criture d‚Äôune histoire avec Journey
  • La cr√©ation visuelle de l‚Äôunivers de Last of Us
  • Comment la forme peut na√Ætre de la fonction, le game design au c≈ìur de la cr√©ation, comme pour Splatoon
  • L‚Äô√©criture, plus litt√©raire (dialogues, embranchements) avec Kentucky Route Zero
  • La r√©flexion artistique sur le m√©dium de Tale of Tales

Amusant de noter la multitude de carnets de notes utilis√©s par les concepteurs. Peut-√™tre le seul outil universel.

Un √©cran g√©ant affichait ensuite le grandiose du jeu vid√©o √† travers les affrontements en esport ou dans les MMO avec des extraits de League of Legends et EVE Online.

Disrupt

La section suivante servait de rappel n√©cessaire que la politique dans le jeu vid√©o, ce n‚Äôest pas sale.
La sc√©nographie, tr√®s soign√©e, pr√©sentait les diff√©rents sujets avec des intercalaires color√©s sur des tables r√©tro√©clair√©es, dans une ambiance studieuse.
Pour r√©sumer grossi√®rement le propos : l‚Äôindustrie est toujours tr√®s centr√©e sur la culture occidentale dominante.

Play

L‚Äôexposition ne manquait pas de proposer des interactions √† chaque √©tape du parcours, mais le playground final permet de se concentrer sur le fun, l‚Äôexp√©rimentation des appareils physiques et le multi joueur avec des jeux con√ßus pour des festivals, donc parfaits pour √™tre manipul√©s par un grand nombre.

Derni√®re √©tape obligatoire, la boutique, semble bien petite et laiss√©e pour compte, l‚Äôunivers de Splatoon est tellement con√ßu autour de la surconsommation que je m‚Äôattendais √† √™tre submerg√© de goodies.

La s√©lection de jeux √©tait une tr√®s bonne surprise : √©clectique et pertinente. Comme Journey, premier titre expos√©, qui est une ≈ìuvre esth√©tiquement magnifique et facile √† aborder mais qui renferme plus de complexit√©, comme le r√©v√©lait le prototype des m√©caniques multijoueurs.
Cette exposition √©tait un plaisir √† explorer, les nombreux aspects du m√©dium √©taient enchain√©s avec fluidit√©. M√™me si elle m√©ritait un plus grand espace, nous nous sentions un peu √† l‚Äô√©troit.

Plus de photos et vid√©os

Fin

entry.title: GDC ‚Äô18 Talks Selection
entry.content:
Last month, while the 2019 edition of the Game Developers Conference was taking place, I watched the lecture from the previous year. Here is a personal selection of free videos from the GDC Vault:

  • The Art of ‚ÄòWonder Boy: The Dragon‚Äôs Trap‚Äô
    Ben Fiquet
    The art director, and only artist, behind the visually stunning platformer remake delivers a comprehensive making of.

  • #1ReasonToBe
    Rami Ismail, Samer Abbas, Matthieu Rabehaja, Carlos Rocha, Lara Noujaim, Javi Almirante, Irina Moraru
    Uncommon panel of six speakers from usually unsolicited part of the world.

  • Inside the Indie Mind: Zach Barth (Zachtronics)
    The crazy guy behind the crazy puzzle games discusses many topics during this interview.

  • The 2018 Indie Soapbox
    I love this batch of microtalks, my favorites:

    • What makes people continue to want to play? from Davey Wreden: interesting aimless thoughts about video game concepts.
    • Life = Pain + Video Games from Danny Baranowsky: super interesting talk about pain.
    • On life goals from Adriel Wallick
    • The curse of min-maxing from Justin Ma (Subset games): about game neuroses.
    • The T√≥th Sausage Conjecture from Frank Lantz: it's not about video games but who cares.

  • Don‚Äôt Break the Chain: Maintaining Productivity on Your 19th Game
    Jason Rohrer
    Feedback, with plenty of data, on how to work alone, from the man behind One Hour One Life.

  • ‚ÄòHorizon Zero Dawn‚Äô: A Game Design Postmortem
    Eric Boltjes
    Great postmortem of the development phases and the lessons learned by the game design team while building their first open-world game. With a rare look at early prototypes.

  • Dealing with Scope Change in ‚ÄòHeat Signature‚Äô and ‚ÄòGunpoint‚Äô
    Tom Francis
    Feedback on his experience of scope creep.

  • Weaving 13 Prototypes into 1 Game: Lessons from 'Edith Finch'
    Ian Dallas
    Interesting to see how much this beloved game changed.

  • Making the World Give a Damn About Your Game in 2018
    No More Robots‚Äô Mike Rose
    Up to date (for 2018) presentation on how to smartly market a game.

  • Queens of the Phone Age: The Narrative Design of ‚ÄòReigns: Her Majesty‚Äô
    Leigh Alexander
    Powerful feminist lecture on her role writing a female centric game.

  • Failing to Fail: The Spiderweb Software Way
    Jeff Vogel
    Loved this human and funny experience from the oldest indie developer.

Bonus

Through the suggestions of YouTube, I ended up watching this great talks from other editions:

  • Trailer Made: What Makes a Successful and Memorable Game Trailer
    Derek Lieu, 2019
    I love trailers, and especially game trailers, so I liked to hear advice, even not groundbreaking, from a professional making them.

  • Owlboy: The Motivational Power of Inspiration
    Simon Stafsnes Andersen, 2017
    The artist of Owlboy shares his deep experience making the game during nine years.

  • How to Survive in Gamedev for Eleven Years Without a Hit [How to Survive in Gamedev for Eleven Years Without a Hit]
    Jake Birkett, 2016
    Funny and honest 10+ years indie game dev career experience.

  • How To Make Your Game Just Completely Hilarious: The Stanley Parable
    William Pugh, 2015
    He's making humour using the format of talk as he used, with Davey Wreden, the video game format for The Stanley Parable, so I had a fair amount of laughs.

and more

All 442 videos from 2017 are now free on GDC Vault: https://gdcvault.com/browse/gdc-17/?&media=v

There is an alternative web app easier to browse, with the videos since 2016: GDC Vault Explorer

Fin

entry.title: Post-mortem of my tiny JS web app "Archives"
entry.content:
Some takeaways from the development of archives.thenew.fr.

Backstory

When I ended up on the portfolio of my old colleague Ilk, I thought I should save screenshots of my previous projects. And I liked so much the way AREA 17 was hosting theirs archives I decided to simply steal it.

Besides the nostalgic trip through my old projects, thanks again archive.org, I wanted to make the smallest JavaScript app possible.

Tech

  • Node.js still doesn‚Äôt support ECMAScript Modules,
    The ‚Äî-experimental-modules flag can be used to enable the feature, but only with .mjs files.
    ECMAScript Modules | Node.js v11.11.0 Documentation
    nodemon can also be used with it.

  • Building an HTTP server with Node.js is so simple thanks to the http core module. No need of Express, even if it covers more cases, without any doubts.
    For example, I had troubles with the Content-Type of my responses, I had to specify it, surely because of the configuration of my Debian machine.
    I first did it manually but then used serve-static module for the static files.

  • I tried to make it as simple as possible, so the projects' name were automatically drawn from the directories‚Äô name. A few obscure encoding issues with my server later, I had to introduce weird helpers functions to resolve them. But still no need to edit a config file or a JS object to add or update a project. üôå
    But for any bigger website, it‚Äôs criminal to rely on the folders‚Äô name.

Build

  • To bundle my app in a smaller package, I chose to try Rollup, which is the main solution to build Node.js packages. You can easily change the settings to build an app to be used for a browser instead of Node.js.
    I wanted to avoid webpack to try something simpler and smaller.

  • Final touch : adding analytics tracking. With nothing better than Google Analytics suiting my needs, I added the package universal-analytics.
    Issue : the rollup build is not compatible with the package‚Äôs code.
    I had to exclude it from the build with

external: [‚Äòuniversal-analytics‚Äô]

in rollup.config.js and copy it to the production server. Not nice.

I should look at Fathom and Matomo to replace Google Analytics in the future, this will ask more work or money.

Hosting

  • I wanted to try Heroku for a long time and gave them a shot. The whole experience is good and the integration of GitHub pretty, but I somehow missed the important downside of this free offer: each app goes to sleep (idle) after 30 min if not used.
    And the problem is the load of a page will suddenly take around 30 seconds. So, no good, for my tiny, confidential app.
    Back to my personal hosting.

  • I fumbled to find a working configuration for the apache virtual host :

<VirtualHost *:80>
  ServerAlias archives.thenew.fr
  ErrorLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/error.log

  DocumentRoot /path/to/archives

  ProxyPreserveHost On

  ProxyPass / http://127.0.0.1:4100/
</VirtualHost>

  • I‚Äôm using pm2 to manage Node applications on the server and let them run in the background as a service. With the -‚Äîwatch parameter to see the change in production after each deploy: PM2 - Watch & Restart
    A good tutorial to setup a Node.js app for production.

  • GitLab CI offers free solutions to deploy to a server:
    GitLab Build and Deploy to a Server via SSH ‚Äì codeburst

Thanks for reading, I hope those bits could help other web tinkerers.

entry.title: Ways to play: Subscription based
entry.content:

entry.title: Putain 3 years!
entry.content:
Today I‚Äôm starting my fourth year with Build in Amsterdam.
I moved to Amsterdam for Build or to Build for Amsterdam, I can‚Äôt remember. I was already too old for this lunacy, and I‚Äôm not younger.

First experience abroad and first experience in English. My journey with Build shares a lot with the city itself, this contained craziness, this taste for well designed edginess and this organised chaos.

It‚Äôs a place where I can use my craftsmanship on tasty projects to serve the client‚Äôs brand, products and identity but also aiming to offer the best possible experience to the customer.
I feel lucky to be able to juggle between back and front end, from SVG animations to connecting APIs, building design systems and WordPress plugins.
Trying to merge the experimental and surgical design with functional and accessible digital shops.
Not to mention the chance to work with utterly nice people at adidas.

I‚Äôm proud to be part of a company promoting a good work-life balance, horizontal organisation and fighting against a toxic pitch-oriented industry.

And above all this, my colleagues, past or present, the best bunch of weirdos, are all so damn pretty, from the inside to the outside. I still can‚Äôt cope with it.

So thanks wonderful beings for pushing me, trusting me and making me feel I still have a world to discover and learn.

entry.title: 2019 Awards
entry.content:
Better later than never, let‚Äôs go back to last year‚Äôs art production.

Cinema

I watched 114,5 films this year (the half is because I didn't know Woodstock was 5h 30m when I entered the cinema) including 33 released in 2019 and a lot of great classics.

üèÜ Booksmart
Perfect, love it.

I confess my enthusiasm has decreased a bit since but I was really into it for a month. It was the first time I was able to watch a movie on streaming (Netflix) after seeing it in cinema and I did, multiple times.

  • Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood

Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt are amazing. The tension builds up leads to an exultant finale, the best you can expect from a Tarantino film.

  • Avengers Endgame

The climax of an unprecedented shared universe list of films. I admit I got the chills, I cried and yelled with all the movie theatre.

  • Ad Astra

What an odd mix, kind of a personal, introspect, pulp space adventure. I was blown away just at the cinematography (Hoyte Van Hoytema) of some scenes. The music, with tracks from Max Richter (damn!), also moved me.

I'm missing good space opera nowadays! Too bad the last part is too ridiculous.

Mentions

I want to cite many more films that I all liked for their uniqueness:

  • J'ai perdu mon corps
  • Art of selft defense
  • Marriage story
  • Parasite
  • Mid 90's

TV

üèÜ Watchmen
What a tour de force! The sequel of a cult and complex comics that respect the original material by being as controversial. Playing with the TV media and the audience like the graphic novel did.

An A-class world-building. Smart Easter eggs. Interesting extra content for the community. It's a masterclass. The official podcast with Damon Lindelof himself is indicative of the passion and work provided.

I loved the work on transitions in the first episodes.

For the third time, Lindelof delivers an outstanding show, and soundtrack: this time with Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, but Max Richter and Michael Giacchino did it before.

Mentions

  • The Good Place S3
    Oh my god! The final moral is following me every day. Best sci-fi show, best ethics show.
  • Love, Death & Robots
    Varying quality but one ground breaking short: The Witness (and Zima is beautiful)
  • Russian Doll
  • Carole & Tuesday
  • Star Trek Discovery S2
  • The Witcher
  • Sex education S1
    Too many stupid plots but a Freaks and Geeks vibe! Mama Gillian is great.
  • Osmosis
    A tacky French sci-fi mixing all plots possible instead of focusing on its good initial idea but I could watch the soulless gaze of Agathe Bonitzer all day.

My top on SensCritique

Music video

To be honest, at the end of the year, I had no idea which music videos to feature, except maybe this two from -M- (the so Moulin Rouge Superch√©rie and this impressive fake oner Th√©rapie).

So I went hunting and found a bunch of interesting videos but üèÜ Hungry Child from Saman Kesh for Hot Chip is the best one. I just finished Silicon Valley, so I'm surely biased, but the actors are great, the concept fun and the track cool.
I'll continue to dig into Saman Kesh's work, this bit is also great: Too Many Friends by Placebo.

Mentions

The Chemical Brothers‚Äô videos are always qualitative and 2019 is not an exception:

We‚Äôve Got to Try directed by Ninian Doff (also great videos for Miike Snow) and Got To Keep On directed by Michel Gondry & Olivier Gondry, of course.

PUP had really stupid videos as well: a fan made Free at Last and a low-key sci-fi Kids.

In the category "Film director still making music videos", Paul Tomas Anderson has a pretty strong game

Summer Girl for HAIM is the most summery strip and Anima with Thom Yorke is, less bathed in light, but impressive.

Finally, I love the camera work on Vossi Bop - Stormzy, the bullet time in Kids Turned Out Fine - A$AP Rocky by Dexter Navy and this eerie moment in Doin‚Äô Time when giant Lana Del Rey (?) is dancing on the beach, on a driving cinema screen. Yeah.

Video

HOOD COWBOY BEBOP by King Vader

Best Cowboy Bebop adaptation. This left-right camera move is killing me every time, reminds me this too short FX during the final fight scene of Elysium by Neill Blomkamp.

Music

  • Lettre infinie - -M-
  • No Geography - Chemical Brothers
  • Watchmen and mid90s - Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross
  • Metronomy for Ever and Nights Out (10th Anniversary Edition) (Over track üëå) - Metronomy
  • Better Oblivion Community Center

My Last.fm profile

Video game trailer

Can I be disappointed that the best video game trailer of the year is for a flight simulator? Yes, I am but the X019 - Gameplay Trailer is still amazing. The music, the edit and, of course, the fraking graphics from the upcoming üèÜ Microsoft Flight Simulator, by the French Asobo, **are moving. And they are already getting back at it with Let it snow! trailer in 2020.

Mentions

I really feel I missed something but the best Cyberpunk 2077 trailer was last year despite the Official Cinematic Trailer E3 2019. The Breath of the Wild Sequel trailer caused a sensation but is lazy. Control has an astonishing art direction and trailers had nothing to do to show it.

Deathloop was a nice surprise from the Arkane Lyon and its E3 2019 trailer is solid.

Death Stranding is out-of-category, more than one trailer, it's the 3-year campaign led by Kojima's videos that I want to celebrate.

I loved the introduction of Super Smash Bros. Ultimate Banjo-Kazooie Official Trailer - E3 2019 and all their characters‚Äô videos are entertaining.

I almost forgot the Official Announcement Trailer for Humankind from the Frenchies Amplitude, with a crazy cover of the Toccata and Fugue in D Minor by Bach, maybe from FlyByNO ¬Ø*(„ÉÑ)*/¬Ø

And there was a trailer for a new Half-life game but it's not fun, contrary to this French gem, worst, but funny, dub of the year: Ring Fit Adventure - Vid√©o de pr√©sentation

Video game

Still difficult to follow the video game calendar but I‚Äôve caught up on some good games this year. I finished Life is Strange, among others. That pushed me to listen to even more of Syd Matters music, always a pleasure.

üèÜ Tetris 99

A bit like the late 1 vs. 100, it's a bloody last man standing but playing Tetris. The oldest perfect game design matching with the latest trend, the battle royale. So smart. The execution and choice of distribution are also very good and unexpected.

Mentions

Meditations was a superb idea but felt short, with me, because the few games I tried were more depressing and frustrating than relaxing.

Pokemon Shield was a nice throwback to my late Pokemon days but the game is from another age, it‚Äôs baffling.

But it was the Xbox Game Pass year for me, the offer is ridiculously good and it's coming to PC. I discovered the excellent Slay the Spire.
I loved the aesthetics of Void Bastards but didn't follow up, cf my relation with rogue likes in last year's awards.
I'm playing A Plague Tale : Innocence, I've started Outer Wilds but haven't been hooked, I'll retry.

And I definitely want to play Death Stranding, Disco Elysium, Control and maybe Baba is You if I feel smart enough.

My top on SensCritique

Fin

entry.title: Mes trailers JV les plus marquants (r√©tro 2010)
entry.content:
Je r√©√©dite un article de mon ancien blog, datant de 2010, titr√© Mes bandes annonces de jeu vid√©o les plus marquantes.
Il n‚Äôa pas vraiment vieilli en 10 ans, mais j‚Äôen profite pour ajouter quelques notes.

Le m√©dia jeu vid√©o, bien plus mall√©able que le cin√©ma, repousse les limites de la pratique de la bande-annonce. Le trailer est clairement une production √† lui seul et m√©rite qu‚Äôon s‚Äôy attarde. Le jeu vid√©o offre une chose tr√®s rare dans le cin√©ma, des passages in√©dits dans ses bandes-annonces, elles se multiplient m√™me √† grande vitesse alors que les trailers de films se limitent √† deux ou trois avec un teaser pour les gros projets.
Je verrai bien un troph√©e pour la meilleure B-A de jeu vid√©o dans les futures c√©r√©monies de r√©compense, en attendant je liste celles qui m‚Äôont marqu√© (c‚Äôest subjectif √©videmment) et qui ont innov√©.

GTA IV

‚ñ∏ Teaser de Grand Theft Auto IV

Les vid√©os Rockstar sont toutes d‚Äôune grande qualit√©, elles marient parfaitement la culture populaire et des r√©f√©rences √† des ≈ìuvres plus alternatives, plus pointues. Ce teaser fut le premier aper√ßu du GTA next-gen et se permet de rendre hommage au film exp√©rimental Koyaanisqatsi et sa superbe BO par Philip Glass.
Les phrases, bien √©crites et bien jou√©es, r√©sonnent encore.

[2020] Depuis, j‚Äôai pu voir un m√©morable cin√© concert de Koyaanisqatsi √† la Philharmonie de Paris et Philip Glass est peut-√™tre l‚Äôartiste que j‚Äôai le plus vu en live. Pas mal pour le teaser qui a aussi enfanter le Rick Roll.

Halo 3

‚ñ∏ L‚Äôannonce d‚ÄôHalo 3

D‚Äôordinaire, je trouve les teasers inutiles, mais celui-l√† est terriblement bien foutu et ne se contente pas de panneaux de titres avec grosses voix. R√©alis√© avec le moteur du jeu, il est bien cadr√© et les paroles de Cortana, ainsi que son incrustation, ne laissent pas indiff√©rent : "This is the way the world ends", j‚Äôadore la sonorit√© de cette phrase, on la retrouve d‚Äôailleurs dans Southland Tales.
Pour finir, comme toujours avec Halo, c‚Äôest la musique de O‚ÄôDonnell qui emballe le tout dans une atmosph√®re √©pique unique, quelques notes de pianos suffisent √† donner des frissons.
Je vous conseille le making of consacr√© uniquement √† ce teaser.

[2020] Les d√©boires entre O‚ÄôDonnel et Bungie sont bien tristes aujourd‚Äôhui, mais je vous conseille ce concert incroyable du Danish National Symphony Orchestra.

Tony Hawks project 8

‚ñ∏ Tony Hawks project 8

Tout d‚Äôabord, je pensais que ce trailer √©tait pour le jeu d‚ÄôEA Skate, qui pr√¥nait ce retour aux sources plus simu face aux Tony Hawk tr√®s arcade d‚ÄôActivision.
En utilisant le moteur du jeu, les ralentis d√©voilaient des animations fines et portaient tr√®s bien le message du revirement de la licence.
La musique si importante dans ces vid√©os est parfaite : Club Foot de Kasabian.

Assassin‚Äôs Creed

‚ñ∏ Assassin‚Äôs Creed

Planant, ralentis, d√©couverte d‚Äôun univers, d‚Äôun personnage.
La bande-annonce √©tait plus belle dans mes souvenirs, la musique collait plus avec l‚Äôensemble ou alors jurait carr√©ment. La vid√©o reste une belle entr√©e dans le jeu.

[2020] Une autre vid√©o avec TearDrop : ‚ñ∏ Assassin's Creed TV Spot

Les vid√©os d'Assassin‚Äôs Creed, et plus largement d‚ÄôUbi Soft, sont de plus en plus l√©ch√©es, mais manquent d'originalit√© et de personnalit√©. Il suffit de regarder le trailer d‚Äôannonce du nouveau AC Valhalla.
Exception faite du tout r√©cent et excellent Reclaim Your Future par Alberto Mielgo.

Little Big Planet

‚ñ∏ Little Big Planet "My Patch"

Utiliser des phases de jeu dans de vrais niveaux pour la promo est √©vident pour un jeu dont le concept est "cr√©er, partager, jouer" et si, en plus, c‚Äôest bien fait, le r√©sultat sort du lot.
La chanson My Patch de Jim Noir est un tr√®s bon choix, on retrouve l‚Äôhumour, la fra√Æcheur et l‚Äôoriginalit√© de la vid√©o et du jeu en g√©n√©ral.

Star Wars The Old Republic

‚ñ∏ Star¬†Wars The¬†Old Republic "Deceived"

R√©alis√© par Blur pour LucasArts et Bioware, on rentre l√† dans le trailer blockbuster sous-trait√©. C‚Äôest tellement √† l‚Äôouest par rapport √† ce qu‚Äôon voit du jeu (un MMORPG au style cartoon) qu‚Äôon pourrait le classer dans le court m√©trage. Mais c‚Äôest magnifique !
Les vid√©os Square et Blur sont vraiment le top du trailer jeu vid√©o CGI (images de synth√®se pr√©calcul√©es) : les cin√©matiques de Halo¬†Wars, la derni√®re BA de Deus¬†Ex 3, les Assassin‚Äôs¬†Creed aussi.
Pour l‚ÄôE3 2010, ils ont remis √ßa avec Hope.

[2020] Blur est toujours au top du game. R√©cemment, ils ont produit beaucoup de courts pour l'omnibus Love, Death and Robots de Netflix.
J'ajoute la collection compl√®te de vid√©os de Blur pour Star Wars The Old Republic :

‚ñ∏ Deceived

‚ñ∏ Hope

‚ñ∏ Return ‚Äì Cinematic Intro

‚ñ∏ Knights Of The Old Republic ‚ÄúSacrifice‚Äù

‚ñ∏ Knights Of The Eternal Throne ‚ÄúBetrayed‚Äù

Battlefield Bad Company 2

‚ñ∏ Battlefield Bad Company 2 annonce de la Beta

Dans le cin√©ma, certains se sont pris la t√™te √† faire des plans ‚Äútime-freeze‚Äù comme dans cet √©pisode des Experts. Dans le jeu vid√©o, rien de plus simple, tout est effets sp√©ciaux, les mod√®les 3D sont l√†, suffit de s‚Äôamuser avec. Le jeu de manipulation du temps, ou d‚Äôautres lois de la physique, sont pourtant assez rares dans les pubs ou les m√©caniques du jeu vid√©o (heureusement qu‚Äôil y a les puzzles).

Bionic Commando Rearmed 2

‚ñ∏ Bionic¬†Commando Rearmed¬†2

Ce n‚Äôest clairement pas une grande BA ni un grand jeu, en fait, je me fous presque compl√®tement du visuel, mais la musique et les bruitages me trottent dans la t√™te avec une insistance rare.

Il en reste un nombre incalculable, je citerai les v√©ritables sketches anim√©s sur les personnages de Team Fortress 2, les classieux et loufoques vid√©os de Kojima pour Metal Gear, la s√©rie pour Mini Ninjas, le Gears of War "Mad World" et d‚Äôautres qui me reviendront √† l‚Äôesprit.

Fin

entry.title: Best films intros
entry.content:
Alien

It‚Äôs not a news, the introduction sequence of Alien is remarkable. Ridley Scott decided to spend a few minutes of the film wandering in an empty spaceship.
The story unfolds from an unanticipated wake up, but we just witness what is not happening before the event.
The sequence showcases the amazing production design: the industrial art by Ron Cobb, the icons (and more) designed by Mo√´bius. Even if they used technologies from the time of the filming, like CRT screens, this aesthetics became timeless, kind of retrofuturism.
The production was so thought and the fact that the director took the time to share and enjoy the art of the design team is wonderful.
It‚Äôs shorter than I remember, just three minutes in reality, but became iconic.

Back to the Future

The cinematography is splendid, the type design of the credits is ageless, the long shots are mastered, it's Zemekis of course. He's not afraid of cutting the long takes when needed.
The sequence is foreshadowing the plot, portraying the characters while depicting the film's subject: the time. And the scene ends with an explosion of 80s Power of love and skateboard.

Speed Racer

The Wachowskis proved their editing skills with Cloud of Atlas and Sense8 where the stories stay clear even if they jump between timelines, time zones and characters. But the introduction of Speed Racer is still their most flamboyant example.

Alternating between a present scene where Speed is racing against his big browser‚Äôs ghost, figuratively because he left the family and literally as a video game race ghost like and flashbacks presenting Speed.
The -flawless- alternation is classic but the most vivifying thing is the crescendo. The tension is building up and I'm just hooked until the last part. Tough to follow up on this but the film is showing incredible resources.
The sequence is 17 minutes non-stop of introduction to the characters and their traumas and to the unique and unconventional film style, all this during a race. Everything the film is about: race for family and respect.
As the first film of the duo after Matrix, it's a direct hit in the jaw, without any foreplay.

Booksmart

I just love the lines from Amy (Kaitlyn Dever) in the car and how she delivers them, and the stupidly free dance moves after. The short cameo of Maya Rudolph is the cherry on the cake.

Every time, I'm just watching the introduction, I can‚Äôt stop until Billie Lourd is yelling, "Keep it down out there!" a few minutes later.

Kung Fu Panda

I'm a geek for animation and I was in art school when the film came out. I studied this animated introduction and try to copy it. It reminds me the work of Genndy Tartakovsky on Samurai Jack but with even more time and/or budget. This balance between traditional 2D animation and computer particles and clothes animation has been rarely matched.
This intro just overcame the rest of the film, which aged poorly in comparison. It was high quality but that's the problem with 3D animation.

Reservoir Dogs

I don‚Äôt tip and back then, when I watched the film, I didn‚Äôt even know what a tip was but this debate about tipping stayed with me until today. This mundane talk with random people starts like a down-to-earth movie until the opening fades into Mr X bleeding and moaning in the backseat.
Only small details can give up the gangster side of the group: the suits, Mr Pink, the killing joke.

The cult opening of the men in black walking in the alley with a bad slow motion inspired so many. Easy to find it on a tee-shirt.
Amazing to see that the Tarantino openings aesthetic is already in place.

The Graduate

Tarantino has so many memorable opening scenes but the travelling from Jacky Brown resembles the opening of The Graduate (1967). Simon & Garfunkel's music, a zoom out shot in the plane and "one shot" on the moving walkway.
And the film ends with an incredible last shot, mixing hope, jubilation and meaninglessness, reprising the Sound of Silence.

Arrival

Another example of mirrored music, this time with Max Richter.
The trivia is that it was a temp track but none of J√≥hann J√≥hannsson‚Äôs attempts convince Villeneuve to replace it.
The end reflects the beginning with the same shot, same music. It‚Äôs an easy way to close a story but matches smartly the concept of the alien language in the movie.

Mr Right

This music is magic, perfect to wake up in a good mood, and Sam Rockwell's dance moves are pretty nice.

And …

I also think about Apocalypse Now and The Door‚Äôs This is the end. Funny for an intro, which is not funny at all.

The opening credits mixing music and slow motion of Watchmen. It‚Äôs almost the only original addition in this straight up adaptation of the comics.

I love the soundtrack by Daft Punk for Tron legacy. Weirdly, my favourite part of the film is everything outside the computer world and mainly the beginning, the instalment of the story and what happens since the first episode.

Conclusion

I took the luxury to skip the introduction in a post about introductions but I'll try to conclude.

The opening has to deliver the keys to comprehend the universe of the fiction. It has to introduce a tone, a style of narration, a world with its own new rules, characters and places.
It can be silent or dialogue heavy, truthful to the rest of the movie or not, personally, if I'm not hooked after it, it‚Äôs missing the point.

All films introductions I like hold the core feeling of what the film wants to tell: a hero‚Äôs dream or despair, a a yet untold world to explore, ‚Ä¶.
Convey this very essence while welcoming the spectator is the purpose of the introduction.

Fin

entry.title: RadioKawa Retrospective postmortem
entry.content:
version audio, music: Sappy by Neil D. Voss

To honour the end of the French-speaking podcast network RadioKawa, with whom I have worked since 2015, I designed and developed this retrospective website: https://retrospective.radiokawa.com/.

I gathered the timeline, inspirations and some thoughts for a postmortem.

While I was working on complex websites, doing more backend than frontend in my day-to-day work, I was searching to do more web animations and reconnect a bit with GSAP.
RadioKawa has tons of content (shows, authors, categories, episodes, etc.) I‚Äôm aware of and is a non-profit organisation, so it was a good client to animate some big numbers on my free time.

Timeline

I started noodling the design around 9 February 2020 and then send a message to the RadioKawa team to share my idea and a first mock-up on the 24th. I was glad to receive positive feedback.
In March, Yann, the Big Boss, helped me gather appropriate data and collect photographs. On the next three months, during a particularly enjoyable time called lockdown, I streamed, for the first time, some coding sessions.

I continued working on it in the evenings and weekends, slowly but surely. Adding a few, simpler, blocks in the last days. The page was finally launched on the 3rd of July.

Design

My first wish in this project was to play around with Figma and I got more accustomed with it. I‚Äôm still missing some features from Illustrator but it‚Äôs an amazing tool and web-based, so you can share it in a blink of an eye. You can try my font plugin, by the way ;).

Not being a designer, I want to stress it, my biggest mistake was to not choose a correct format/ratio to work on, way too much high, it did not correspond to any realistic devices viewports. So the transition to development was a bit tricky.

Then, while finishing the development, I realised I totally ignored mobile version, which is pretty foolish. I thought it would be complicated to redesign this big blocks in a small viewport, but it was less a conundrum than expected. It made me test the Figma Mirror mobile app, which is awesome to live preview on your device, it‚Äôs literally just log in and play.

Development

I started to code my own scroll animation manager but ScrollTrigger was announced and released just at the beginning of the development so I quickly drop my draft to try the new toy from Greensock.
It‚Äôs well done and kills ScrollMagic, IMHO. The debug tools are nice, but I‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll ever get used to the syntax. As an efficient but limited framework, it was perfect for this kind of project.

I wanted to try replicate this wrapped typography animation with just CSS and JS. I know they are made with WebGL but when you see how complex it is, I wanted to play dumb. So I‚Äôm surprised it kinda works visually but the performances are terrible, will not recommend.
This was my swan song of dumb HTML animations before jumping on the GL train, maybe.

In the same idea of ‚Äã‚Äãplaying low-key, I didn‚Äôt want to code any lazy loading for the assets so I tried the HTML version: if you want a quick lazy loading, the loading img attribute (mdn, web.dev) is a nice native feature, you don‚Äôt have control on the loading of the images but it‚Äôs plug-and-play.
Just one thing to consider: if the image is on position: fixed the browser will load it immediately so you should change the image styles with JavaScript after the document load: put the position to fixed or remove a display: none, for example.

I had to abandon some designs by lack of time, I‚Äôm still glum about it.

Finally, thanks to Valockar for putting it on a new subdomain for more premium feeling ‚ú®

Refs

The Spotify annual reports were the main inspiration, they are sadly almost impossible to browse again but we have some case studies:

  • Spotify Wrapped 2018 and Active Theory‚Äôs great case study

  • An analysis of Spotify Wrapped 2019

  • I love Area17 design and its 2019 report was an inspiration, especially the first hero block, obviously: https://2019.area17.com/

  • Cineville, a Dutch cinema subscription, did a good job with its year report: https://filmblik.cineville.nl/

  • Or random Corn Flakes box cover ¬Ø_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

entry.title: 2020 Awards
entry.content:
I had more free time in this pandemic year of 2020 but the morale was not always there to enjoy all this artistic production which only slowed down slightly. I have been fortunate to experience many films in theatres but going to live music is what I missed the most and I don‚Äôt see it happening again in the near future. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs related but a lot of the best of this year is uplifting comedy and aplenty original creations.

Cinema

I watched 120,5 films this year (I caught up on the second half of Woodstock from last year) including 20 released in 2020.
But also so many great classics I recommend, mainly from the 80s: The Hunt for Red October, The Big Blue, Paris, Texas, Goodfellas, The Blues Brothers, Phenomena, Footloose, Mississippi Burning, My Own Private Idaho, The Bear, Brazil, The Grand Budapest Hotel and Network.

I had the weirdest experience in theatre watching the crazy Punch-Drunk Love film. I will always remember more the cashier running after us taking the ferry than the film itself :D

üèÜ Jojo Rabbit

It‚Äôs just the funniest film of the year for me. The cinematography, editing and actors‚Äô performances are top-notch.

Mentions

  • Tenet
    It‚Äôs funny that a film telling directly the spectators to feel it instead of trying to understand it generates so many reactions about the difficulty to make sense of it. I enjoyed it for the spectacular show it delivers in a theatre. The time reversed concept has one or two smart uses. The flaws are easy to spot (characters, dialogues, etc.) and often saw in other Christopher Nolan‚Äôs films.
  • 1917
    My only complaint is that the (fake) one-shot technical implementation is distracting a lot from the story and the emotion of the events.
  • Onward
    Better than what the trailer was advertising, Pixar surprised me again but I felt that this original world was underused.

TV

üèÜ Ted Lasso

It‚Äôs so comforting to experience positive characters that are not naive. Ted Lasso is human, he has limits but he‚Äôs still trying to bring the best of every person and situation. I‚Äôm happy to see Jason Sudeikis getting some spotlight. It worths Apple TV+ subscription, at least for a month.

Mentions

  • Middleditch & Schwartz is the best comedy of the year, the best improved show I ever saw.

  • Dave

  • I loved the eerie San Francisco of Devs, the actors (Sonoya Mizuno astonished me again after Maniac) and the not-too-long story of this miniseries.

  • Avenue 5: I still don‚Äôt know if the humour is bad or it‚Äôs just my taste but it makes me laugh.

  • Mythic Quest: Raven‚Äôs Banquet
    Merely for the episode A Dark Quiet Death, the best episode of this year, thanks to Jake Johnson and Cristin Milioti. It‚Äôs a stand-alone episode so you can only watch this one.

  • Star Wars: The Clone Wars S7
    For this finale season, you can skip to the last four episodes, they received more care and are more sombre since they are happening in parallel to Episode III.

One trend I lament is the spread of early spin-offs: the beginning of the last season of Clone Wars on Disney+ was a setup for The Bad Batch spin-off.
Still on Disney+, Mandalorian season 2 starts two or three new spin-offs: Ahsoka, Rangers of the New Republic and The Book of Boba Fett.
Not far from Star Wars, Star Trek Discovery paused its season 4 with a double episode just to prepare Michelle Yeoh‚Äôs spin-off Section 31. Another spin-off is coming with characters from the previous season: Star Trek: Strange New Worlds.

My top on SensCritique

Podcast

By the number of hours listened in 2020, French-speaking podcasts only, d√©so pas d√©so:

  1. üèÜ Super Cin√© Battle
  2. Le Cosy Corner
  3. 2 heures de perdues
  4. LOL Japon
  5. Capture mag
  6. Les D√©mons du MIDI
  7. Total Trax
  8. After Hate
  9. Torr√©faction

Music video

üèÜ ALL OUT EP videos by K/DA

After the amazing POP/STARS video from 2018, K/DA comes back with an EP of five songs and as many videos. Each video is not groundbreaking by itself, but the overall project is impressive. I will highlight the main one MORE: solid video and the song is a banger! The other ones received less budget as THE BADDEST is just a good motion typography video and VILLAIN is a more static but delightful 3D porn. DRUM GO DUM and I‚ÄôLL SHOW YOU are just working.
Besides the videos, I also listened to a lot to the music I find well produced and very entertaining, K/DA should just disable the Caps Lock.

Mentions

  • The Strokes released four interesting videos for The New Abnormal album: At the door with some work from Ugo Bienvenu, Bad Decisions, Ode To The Mets directed by long-time collaborator Warren Fu and The Adults Are Talking directed by another regular Roman Coppola
  • 04:42 Still Free from Haven Original Soundtrack by DANGER
  • Whitsand Bay - Metronomy
  • Gorillaz released nine music videos all along the year for their last album Song Machine, Season One: Strange Timez. They compromised the quality to produce as many videos but they are all different and enjoyable.

Music

My music obsessions of this year:

  • In January: New Obsession by CRX and the whole album PEEK (2019)
  • In July: Minit OST by Jukio Kallio
  • In August: An Acre of Land by PJ Harvey and Harry Escott from Dark River soundtrack. I recommend the long version.
  • In November: More by K/DA, part of the ALL OUT EP.

My Last.fm profile

Video game

üèÜ Streets of Rage 4

Making a new entry in the mythic trilogy was a huge risk but they succeeded in respecting the previous games while updating and perfecting its gameplay. The soundtrack is a massively good surprise, it was impossible to redo SOR2 so Olivier Derivi√®re did its own new thing and the guests (foremost Yuzo Koshiro and Motohiro Kawashima) are doing an excellent job.
But like every year, I didn‚Äôt play most of the 2020 games.

Mentions

  • A Short Hike (2019) was my first lockdown game, a lovely blue sky game. Wide Ocean Big Jacket was my second lockdown game. Nicely written, I believed and loved all the characters. Two perfectly paced short games to go camping or hiking from your bed.

  • Death Stranding
    There are a lot of things in this game, a lot of mishits and some great ideas. Super annoying interface. Surprisingly well paced for a long game, if you don‚Äôt abuse side quests. The world is so poorly introduced, it‚Äôs baffling. But the gameplay is good and the multiplayer part is fitting so well in the universe.

  • Hades
    Another roguelike? OK, this one is pretty visually and musically.

My top on SensCritique

Video game trailer

üèÜ Tipping Point Cinematic Trailer for Watch Dogs: Legion, directed by Alberto Mielgo (pre-production of Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, The Witness in Love, Death & Robots).

Mentions

  • I can‚Äôt say no to a nice Star Wars CG Short: Star Wars: Squadrons - "Hunted"

  • Humankind is back with a silly new trailer LUCY

  • A surprising FINAL FANTASY reveal trailer, with in-game sequences: FF XVI - Awakening

  • Two cool animated space music trailers: Endless Dungeon - Announcement Trailer and Reigns: Beyond - Animated Trailer

Worst

The worst dub of the year award goes to a French trailer again, surely my mother tongue bias, but it‚Äôs even more unbelievable that the previous one:
Que la qu√™te commence ! for Snack World : Mordus De Donjons ‚Äî Gold contains nonsense lyrics, is it bad translation or cryptic jokes?
‚Äúcomme les rebus de l'√©picier du coin‚Äù
‚Äúla jeunesse plein de boules, accro au portable, c'est malsain‚Äù
‚ÄúTrouvons des c√¥tes de porc, d√©gustons les, mettons nous √† l‚Äôaise‚Äù

Film trailer

üèÜ The Batman - DC FanDome Teaser

Mentions

  • The Green Knight teaser

  • Palm Springs Trailer

  • Promising Young Woman has two trailers with equally good edits: Trailer and Trailer 2

Worst

The whole endeavour behind Justice League Snyder's Cut is upsetting, with the hashtag #ReleaseTheSnyderCut for example. I didn‚Äôt find if the finale version will be in black and white but the last trailer is, so much snobbery is hilarious.

Fin

entry.title: My 56 most anticipated films of 2021
entry.content:
This year, I‚Äôve been a bit overboard with 56 films.
All those films should be released in 2021 but nothing is sure any more, so don‚Äôt trust the dates. And, of course, 14 are coming from my expectations of last year.

This year, I‚Äôm less interesting by the delta between expectations and reality and will use this list mostly to pick films from the top and just completely avoid the bottom. "Forcing" myself to watch Bloodshot or Wonder Woman last year was not fun.

Some novelties: HBO Max is becoming a new channel at the expense of Denis Villeneuve, plenty of science fiction and MCU is back :) alongside Sony‚Äôs Marvel :(

  1. Dune by Denis Villeneuve - HBO Max (1¬†October)
    because SF, Denis Villeneuve, the books and the casting
  2. The Matrix¬†4 by Lana Wachowski ‚ôÄ - HBO Max
    significant part of the cast returns but the question remains: why a sequel?
  3. Kaamelott - Premier volet by Alexandre Astier
    a cult French TV comedy finally got its first feature film, I‚Äôm curious
  4. The Batman by Matt Reeves with Robert Pattinson, music by Michael Giacchino

entry.title: 2020 films expectations versus reality
entry.content:
For my first confrontation between reviews and presumptions, I‚Äôve been spoiled with 14 (!) films actually released in 2020 from the 32 films I‚Äôve ranked in my expectations last year.

On every review, next to the title, I indicate the relative predicted rank out of the released films and the evolution with the final rank. And in parentheses, the predicted rank out of the original 32 films.




  1. Soul 6‚¨Ü (12)

Beautiful and moving picture. The moral of the story is fighting directly the "purchase your dream" you can find in the typical American and Disney films. It‚Äôs a relief to see this liberty in the Pixar of today. The film is leaving a lot of space for reflexion while featuring endearing characters. They also took risks on the music but it was necessary as it is at the heart of the subject.

  1. Tenet 1‚¨á (2)

I was lucky to experience it in theatre and I think it makes a great difference on this film. Tenet was exactly like expected, it‚Äôs very good and still too cold.
The general story is a classic time travel (see Looper, Dr Who, In the Shadow of the Moon) and it‚Äôs funny to think about the different time paths but with the twist of the reversed objects. Every detail is well done. The interrogation scene is amazing. The locations are beautiful. The pace is frenetic but the dialogue sounds too flat even if Nolan changes the locations every ten seconds.
It‚Äôs missing a bit of good shots but I liked the zoetrope effect on the car and the ending shot of the last action scene, on top of a dune, is beautiful, it made me awe.

  1. 1917 2‚¨á (4)

It looks really good but the forced/fake one shot was too obvious and put me off. I was expected just a bit more emotion or engaging story but it doesn‚Äôt land so far from my prediction.


  1. Onward 8‚¨Ü (15)

Good surprise, my Pixar expectations are crunched. It gives me so much excitement for the future, compared to the previous Pixar period with many sequels.

  1. Mank 4‚¨á (8)

The film is really focusing on a niche subject and I‚Äôm not amateur of the Hollywood 30s cinema film industry. Mank is well made but I was missing too much context or background to relate to the protagonist. I appreciate Lily Collins and Tuppence Middleton but they look alike so much it got me confused.


  1. Underwater 3‚¨á (7)

Oh! I had great expectations for this one, I was digging the concept.
It‚Äôs vaguely entertaining but shallow: poor directing, tacky slow motions, weird jump cuts, just a series of scenes. The most interesting is the production design but it‚Äôs underused (dashboard, bridge). I understand the deep sea is dark but it‚Äôs not an excuse for the action to be so difficult to follow. Really basic storyline in fact.
Weird balance of badass and humour: TJ Miller character is too much and the others are not iconic.

  1. Eurovision 11‚¨Ü (23)

Another Will Ferrel comedy, nothing more. Nice that even the bad guys are good, Eurovision is good feeling only. Except against the Americans!

  1. Sonic the Hedgehog 9‚¨Ü (20)

It‚Äôs a decent DTV, the best part is the Sonic music cover by John Baptiste (also Soul), it lasts a few seconds, at the end.

  1. The Midnight Sky 7‚¨á (13)

Funny to see again a dad story in a sci-fi contemplative movie after Ad Astra. But this one is lacking the cinematography and the action scenes not to be bland. The finale with a reveal I quite liked should have been the emotional apex but I can‚Äôt interpret the final shot with other than a lack of humanity, really weird. The music by Alexandre Desplat is too much. I would like to like it, but I can‚Äôt recommend it. The ship and the spacewalk scene can be impressive for a space newcomer but it‚Äôs old hat.


  1. The Witches 5‚¨á (11)

It was high on my list because of its amazing director: Robert Zemeckis.
But, sadly, it‚Äôs uneventful. Nothing memorable, the nice shots are predictable. The film has a lot of CGI characters and not so many are great.

  1. Bloodshot 14‚¨Ü (30)

Vin Diesel as an actor, that‚Äôs not possible. We have to do something to stop this.
The film could be as stupid as GI Joe but it‚Äôs too damn serious. The sci-fi concept opens a lot of possible questions on the doubt between reality and real life but they just openly decide not to treat it. In result, it‚Äôs just an excuse to make a cheap 3D building scene.
The film is saved by some good character design and by Lamorne Morris, I love him in New Girl, joyfully playing a hacker fighting evil corporation stealing his open source code.




  1. Wonder Woman 1984 12 ‚û° (24)

WW1984 is an overlong story about a sad, nostalgic, aloof and undying lady.
The dialogues are simpletons, the writing is terrible, the story is not told by actions, the four action sequences are dreadful, everything is over explained for anything but satisfying outcomes.
The fan service is not even enjoyable. And the film concludes on a tasteless stock-shot montage.
Strangely, the contemplative scenes are nice and the fish out of the water part can be funny. I got the feeling the director just wanted to do another film, about flying particularly.


  1. Birds of Prey: And the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn 10‚¨á (21)

Clearly silly but they are trying so so hard to be cool and edgy. Terribly lazy storytelling. Ugly. Lazy choreography. Bad music.

  1. Mulan 13‚¨á (29)

Meh, nothing interesting here. A pale copy of a Chinese, Hong Kong martial film.

Fin

entry.title: One year of desk upgrades
entry.content:
2020/03/16

First ‚Äúsmart‚Äù lockdown, we all moved to remote working from one day to another but it was still fun and games.

2020/03/19

Addition of the office monitor, the migration starts. The Kinect comes out of retirement to finally be useful step-up video calls.

2020/04/10

Office laptop stand has been looted. Still not sure about the second screen.

2020/05/09

The camera tripod is recycled for Kinect. The second screen stand is building up.

2020/07/08

The book made second monitor stand achieved its final form while the main screen shapeshifted.

2020/11/14

The only advantage of a glass desk is to take the red garland off the street window, to write dark poetry in a new first-class ergonomic chair.

2021/01/20

Let‚Äôs try a new trackpad, keyboard, mouse combo.
A second plant joins the battle.

2021/01/29

Serious gear up!
Bye-bye the worthless glass desk, the brand-new desk can stand!
The all-black setup is complete, even the MacBook followed the dark side. Spoiler: it only lasted an evening before colours came ruining it.

2021/01/30

Multicolour LED light strip, backlight mechanical keyboard and Rubik‚Äôs cube are required for a geek ensemble.

2021/03/14

New desk mat, new monitor stand, Kinect on top and new massage ball; is it the ultimate setup?
Don‚Äôt mention cable management, it‚Äôs a passionate journey that should not come to an end.

Take care in home, stay safe out there.

entry.title: Generate and animate a QR code
entry.content:
It‚Äôs easy to generate a QR code but here is simple way to add a bit of fun to its reveal animation.

Bitmap image

QR code or Quick Response code is a 2D barcode that contains information, most usely an URL.

We can easily get one with the Google API but it‚Äôs only a PNG bitmap image.
Just replace put whatever text you want to share at the end of this URL, after chl=: https://chart.googleapis.com/chart?chs=500x500&cht=qr&chl=http://views.thenew.fr/posts/generate-and-animate-a-qr-code

and you will get your visual matrix code:

SVG

But many libraries exist to generate it ourself and therefore choose the output format.
SVG is better than a PNG: we can zoom on it as much as we want, it will stay sharp and it‚Äôs so much lighter, because it‚Äôs vector graphics.

For example, in JavaScript, with node-qrcode:

// JavaScript

const QRCode = require("qrcode")

QRCode.toString(

  // the URL to encode
  "http://views.thenew.fr/posts/generate-and-animate-a-qr-code",
  {
    // the format
    type: "svg"
  },
  function (err, url) {

    // insert the SVG into the HTML element <div id="qrcode"></div>
    document.getElementById("qrcode").innerHTML = url;
  }
)

SVG images are XML files, so we can change the color easily directly in the code or with CSS. But this SVG is containing only one <path> so there is no room to play with it.

Detailed SVG

The PHP QR Code library is also generating a QR code but the SVG output is defining every squares, this time.

// PHP

include 'lib/full/qrlib.php';

echo QRcode::svg("http://views.thenew.fr/posts/generate-and-animate-a-qr-code");

The SVG doesn‚Äôt have one path but as many rect as it has squares. The code is very big compared to the previous SVG but it‚Äôs the price to pay to be able to animate it.
To avoid code repetition, it uses the SVG elements use and defs.

<!-- HTML -->

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xml:space="preserve" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" viewBox="0 0 264 264" title="QR Code to view [URL] on mobile">
  <defs>
    <rect id="p" width="8" height="8" />
  </defs>
  <g fill="#000102">
    <use x="0" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="8" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="16" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="24" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="32" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="40" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="48" y="0" x="152" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="160" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="168" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="176" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="184" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="208" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="216" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="224" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="232" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="240" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="248" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="256" y="0" href="#p" /><use x="0" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="48" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="64" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="80" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="104" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="112" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="120" y="8" href="#p" /><use x="128" y="8" /><use x="64" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="88" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="136" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="144" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="160" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="176" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="184" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="192" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="208" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="232" y="256" href="#p" /><use x="248" y="256" href="#p" />
  </g>
</svg>

By changing the styles of this use elements in CSS, we can animate them randomly from one state to another.

/* CSS */

.qrcode use {
  opacity: 0.01; /* hide */
  transition: opacity 0.05s ease;
}

.qrcode.active use {
  opacity: 1; /* show */
}

/* Add delay to random squares */
.qrcode.active use:nth-child(2n) {
  transition-delay: 0.2s;
}

.qrcode.active use:nth-child(3n) {
  transition-delay: 0.1s;
}

.qrcode.active use:nth-child(4n) {
  transition-delay: 0.4s;
}

.qrcode.active use:nth-child(5n) {
  transition-delay: 0.3s;
}

A bit of JavaScript is adding the .active class and voila!

Misc

  • Google Chrome recently added an option to create a QR code for the current page in the right click menu but we can only download it as a poor quality, branded PNG.

  • Worth noting, the longer the text or URL we are encoding in the QR Code, more complex it will be. So we can have a smaller Flash code, with less rows and columns, by using a URL shortener, for example.

  • I think the average person is still ignoring QR code as the adoption is still really slow after years of uses in many communication support. I guess it‚Äôs just not appealing to scan a gibberish splatter of black and white dots.
    I believe it should be replaced in medium term by a human and machine-readable URL as many modern smartphone can scan text now so the URL would be displayed with some specific graphics around to help the machine to scan.

  • Don‚Äôt forget to add a title attribute to a SVG to make it accesible.

Fin

entry.title: Cinema 88, first part
entry.content:
French audio version, music: Kaneda (from "AKIRA Symphonic Suite") by Geinoh Yamashirogumi

1988 was the year of the first steps of the World Wide Web, the World Expo in Brisbane, the unique time the male football team of The Netherlands has been champion and, closer to me, French president Fran√ßois Mitterrand was reelected.
But more importantely I also came to this world.
So, for no more reason, I decided a few months ago to watch as many films from 88 as possible.

Let‚Äôs start with the films I already saw:

The Obvious Ones

Die Hard

by John McTiernan - Disney+




Bruce Willis was the action hero of my childhood with The Fifth Element. He was like Son Goku: he saves the day without coming out unscathed.
I saw the film a long time ago and thought I remembered it well but after watching it again, I only had in mind the more than iconic moments, and they are plenty: the fire hose, the ventilation ducts, the duct tape in the back, Hans‚Äô fall, etc.

But the film is so generous, it‚Äôs a non-stop ride. The intricate villain‚Äôs plan is slowly unfolding while actions sequences go on. John McClain is smart but not smarter than the bad guys. The German gymnasts are hilarious, Alan Rickman's performance is insane.
The cinematography of Jan de Bont starts in warm Los Angeles sunshine before quickly dives into dark night and high lights.
The directing of McTiernan is only at its best in motion.
I totally forgot that the Christmas music is used all along the movie, it‚Äôs fun and revelling.
The exposition is smart: the first dialogue in the plane introduces the protagonist and is the cause of him being bare feet during the rest of his suffering. The touchscreen at the entrance of the building is a proof of its high technology but also shows to John that his wife changed name. Examples are numerous.

I‚Äôm sure that, as a kid, I also loved the mocking tone. The film is sparing no one: the greedy journalists, the frat boys FBI agents Johnson and Johnson (haha), the imbecile chief of police, the businessman full of coke.

Akira

„Äå„Ç¢„Ç≠„É©„Äç by Katsuhiro Otomo

It‚Äôs still one of the best animated films of all time. I love other works from Otomo in animation or manga. It's a cornerstone of the animation history and a huge influence in cyberpunk aesthetic. We should watch and rewatch it, no doubt.

My Neighbor Totoro

„Äå„Å®„Å™„Çä„ÅÆ„Éà„Éà„É≠„Äç by Hayao Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli

The career of Hayao Miyazaki doesn‚Äôt contain any mistakes, in my opinion, and the character of Totoro is more than iconic so, obviously, I recommend you to see it. It‚Äôs, first of all a film for children and I would have loved to see it earlier, maybe that‚Äôs why Totoro is not in my favourites Miyazaki.

Grave of the Fireflies

„ÄåÁÅ´ÂûÇ„Çã„ÅÆÂ¢ì„Äç by Isao Takahata and Studio Ghibli

It was not a bad year for animation, clearly. I understand the praise for Grave of the Fireflies and it was for a long time in my watch list but it‚Äôs a bit too much tearjerker for my taste. Anecdote: I watched it for the first time in 2018, in a cinema, during a strange screening with technical difficulties and a neighbour eating tacos, so appropriate.

And The First Surprises

They Live

by John Carpenter




So badass and stupid at the same time, it has a real punk feeling. I love Carpenter and am slowly catching up on his films. I was surprised by the groom beginning, I was expecting a more fun satire. They Live is a great melting pot of political critic, cartoonish scenes and a pulp story.

Working Girl

by Mike Nichols - Disney+




I only knew Mike Nichols for The Graduate so I was prepared for some darkness but it‚Äôs well hidden behind a joyful romantic comedy.
Harisson Ford and Sigourney Weaver are having a ball and Kevin Spacey plays an asshole, as always. Melanie Griffith is even more annoying than in Body Double but we could say its na√Øvet√© helps the story.
The boss, Katharine, is smartly portrayed: she knows the tricks, even if younger, to stay at this position of power.
The last scene shows how ecstatic Tess is by her new position, but then the camera slowly backtracks, revealing a different view: she is just another small gear in the machine.
This last shot leaving the city also reflects the nice first shot.

Police Story

„ÄäË≠¶ÂØüÊïÖ‰∫ã„Äã with Jackie Chan

Released in 1985 in Hong Kong, but in 1987 in France and 1988 in USA.

Wow! I love Jacky Chan and I was a big fan as a kid but I wasn‚Äôt aware of this saga until late. I finally catch up and, clearly, I‚Äôm not used (yet) to the HK cinema. It‚Äôs almost just a suite of stunt scenes but the other scenes are surprisingly telling a coherent story. It‚Äôs simple and goofy but you can feel the rage. The sequel has been originally released in 1988 so I‚Äôm looking forward to include it in my next list.

Tucker, the man and his dream

by Francis Ford Coppola - Netflix

First time watching a Coppola film after Apocalypse Now. I didn't expect this over-the-top, joyful, car ride. I liked the too-big-for-life character. Always smiling but also too aggressive with his team.

The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!

by David Zucker

Not the best from the series but still love it, way too salacious.
Some lines are still great ("A parachute not opening‚Ä¶that's a way to die." :D)

The Bear

L‚ÄôOurs by Jean Jacques Annaud

Except some trippy nightmare scenes that don‚Äôt fit with the rest of the film, I enjoyed a lot the cinematography and the journey. The animals are very beautifully filmed. The story is more engaging than I expected. Peculiar shots (close-ups, first person, distorted) are cleverly flavouring the direction.

Dead Ringers

by David Cronenberg


So weird. Adapted from a true story, which makes it even weirder. It‚Äôs touching many topics, from science, gynaecology, fecundity, drugs, identity, links. It's convincing, good performance from Irons but I don‚Äôt grasp the story.
Nice decorum, this late 80s black marble and red surgeon tunics are amazing.
Seeing again a lonely crazy Iron eating birthday cake after the Watchmen TV show was a pleasure.
Pretty subtle for a Cronenberg after all.

Mississippi Burning

by Alan Parker

Some nice dynamic shots. Reminds me of Spielberg. Lots of extras. Army of feds.
Frances McDormand plays a brave, cute and smart character. Gene Hackman is a player, real fun, playing dumber than he is.
Willem Dafoe is so young, he looks almost trustable.
Too bad, the black character with the most lines is a buccaneer from the cop but it‚Äôs a really good scene.
The film takes the time to show that the lawless actions at the end are understandable.
The interviews of the locals are chilling and all the KKK‚Äôs arguments are still in the air today. It‚Äôs revolting.

Red Heat

by Walter Hill




An average 80s buddy movie despite Arnold Schwarzenegger. Almost nothing memorable but some good supporting actors. Laurence Fishburne has a minor role but Gina Gershon is stunning, as always.
It begins with a fight in a hammam and finishes with a bus chase, it could sound hot but it‚Äôs not.
The duo Schwarzy forms with Jim Belushi reminded me the one he has with Tom Arnold in True Lies but Red Heat pales in comparison with James Cameron‚Äôs piece of art.

The Big Blue

Le Grand Bleu by Luc Besson




I like the pace of the movie, even with this length and the narrow main topic.
Jean Reno playing in the Mediterranean reminds me so much Porco Rosso (he did the French dub and I love it), therefore I‚Äôm not objective.
Weird love scene, some stereotypical scenes (thanks Luc!) and wide shots are overused.
The theme can be annoying but the rest of the soundtrack is good, but it's super funky cheesy.

The Little Thief

La Petite Voleuse by Claude Miller

I don't have the context and it‚Äôs not my cinema so I'm not comfortable criticising it. But I felt uncomfortable, to say the least, seeing a 16- or 17-year-old Charlotte Gainsbourg‚Äôs character sex stories.

Who Framed Roger Rabbit

by Robert Zemeckis - Disney+

I love Zemeckis‚Äô works but I avoided this film for a long time because I simply can't stand the Toons: Roger rabbit, Donald duck, Tom & Jerry, etc. they all cringe my gears.
So the movie is a real tour de force and withstands the test of time incredibly well but I'm not a fan of the universe so it was a bit painful to watch.
I will remember the introduction, it‚Äôs a scene for the in-universe cartoon so it's 2D animation but some shots are so dynamic I'm wondering if they used 3D modelling. The fact that I can't see if it's 2D or 3D alone is pretty rare but from a 1988 movie, it‚Äôs impressive.

That‚Äôs all for now,
my watch list of 1988 films is already long and I‚Äôm excited to see some of them but I‚Äôll try to diversify more the genres and explore my discomfort zone.
Feel free to recommend me your favourites ones.

See you next time.

Fin

entry.title: Tracking subscriptions
entry.content:
From how to pay the creators?

After reading a tweet (FR) from @Signez asking how much we are spending every month supporting web creators, I‚Äôve gathered my Patreon subscriptions and other webzines premium accounts. But it raised this recurring question on how I‚Äôm tracking those steady spendings.
By the way, the poll resulted in this initiative, if you are interested: ClubPourcent (FR).

To how to track of all those payments?

I have personal sketches of a web app concept, from maybe ten years ago, to overview all recurring spendings and incomes. Besides subscriptions, many other stable monetary transactions, like rents and salary exist, so I love the idea to visualise all this balance. This idea is still following me and no banking or budget app satisfied me.

I could say that it‚Äôs an even more present challenge with music, video and video game services but I always felt that we have more transactions to track that we can handle (insurance, phone, savings, etc.)

Years ago, I found a simple and nice-looking Dutch app (made in Amsterdam), called Bobby, that was doing a decent job to group all famous subscriptions (Netflix, Xbox, etc.). It was sadly already dead and abandoned back then.

Notion everywhere

So, using Notion for all my notes for a couple of years, I naturally started to list my spending on a new Notion table.

Way too late, I thought of checking out if people already made such a template. This is how I discovered a surprisingly enormous list of templates on Notion Everything. The website is listing Notion templates by categories but is also a marketplace for paid templates, and a lot of them have a pretty premium price tag, above $50.
Here is an interesting thread from its founder about Notion Everything creation.

And there is even an official showcase of templates from Notion themselves.

So, of course, I found (only!) one template doing almost exactly the same as mine: Subscription tracker.

Nevertheless, you can also duplicate my template: Recurring.
It has some other features: cancelled subscriptions are automatically sent to another view and you can have different currencies.

I‚Äôm also exploring how to use Notion as a CMS for a blog or a website and numerous solutions already exist, I will maybe share something later about it.

Fin

entry.title: Cinema 88, second part
entry.content:
After the first list of films from 1988, my hunt is continuing. Difficult to find old movies on the "mainstreaming" platforms so I‚Äôve started looking into Plex, which has, surprisingly, free films to stream with ads. Terrible ads, by the way. So this second part is a mixed bag of hand picked and random movies.

Digging in the carts

Black Eagle

by Eric Karson

Maybe films on Plex are as bad as theirs ads because this one is dreadful.

Black Eagle is about Sh√¥ Kosugi, specialist of ninja films who is not a ninja in this one but a special agent, codename Black Eagle (lol). He will fight against a Russian agent played by a young Jean-Claude Van Damme (just after Bloodsport).
Black Eagle has 2 weeks off, every year, to see his kids but this time, duty doesn‚Äôt wait and the mission is to scuba dive in Malta.

The film is just plain boring, the first fight scene happens after one and half hour and will only be followed by an other one. And they are just bad, the characters are throughing punches like drunk nobodies.
Only two splits, the JCVD signature move.

Just a waste of time.

The Beast

by Kevin Reynolds




Wow! What a great war film!

If we omit the Russians and Afghans played by Americans and that they are both a bit too much caricatural, it‚Äôs a big slap in the face.

From the first scene, the tone is set and I was hooked.
The pace is kept high just to slowly decrease until a final contemplative shot.
I was surprised multiple times by the madness of the leader, the film doesn‚Äôt hold back.
Very smart how The Beast shows the gore of war, either off screen or on screen but fast enough to not be too much, it‚Äôs more about feeling than showing.

The end is interesting, I think the main protagonist thought to have found a more civilised country in Afghanistan. But the women accomplishing their revenge is revealing to him that violence is everywhere, that the vicious circle will not end. Then he gives up on his new brothers in arms and returns home, pulled by another war machine.

Running on Empty

by Sidney Lumet




The scenario flows perfectly, the story looked simple to me at first, a family on the run, but it gives time to care about the main character going through his teenage years, torn between his family and the normal world. I loved the way they wait to show the mother play piano with him.
The end took me away, the unexpected reaction of the father, full of love and reassuring.

The two kids are so touching and endearing. The birthday scene is a very beautiful moment, so joyful that it made me think of the worst that could happen to this family. It touched me easily, without visible artifice, other than the music. I‚Äôm not the only one, this scene often comes up in other reviews. I think it is perfectly placed in the story and serves as a tipping point, the outside world finally pierced the family protective bubble.

From the cinematography to the characters development, everything is simple but beautiful, there is nothing to take out.

Call Me

by Sollace Mitchell

Thanks again Plex to make me discover awful films (for free), this one is an obscure erotic thriller wannabe.

No scenes or dialogues are realistic. There is a murder at the beginning but all the main character is worried about is her phone stalker. And she‚Äôs seduced by him even if he‚Äôs the worst smooth talker ever.
The characters are mentioning multiple times "the Polish bar" like the writers didn‚Äôt bother to give it a name, that was the only funny thing.

I‚Äôm clearly not recommending to watch it! but you can see a young Steve Buscemi and also David Strathairn who was recently in the acclaimed Nomadland (2020).

Police Story 2

„ÄäË≠¶ÂØüÊïÖ‰∫ãÁª≠ÈõÜ„Äã by Jackie Chan


I have mixed feelings, the stunts and fights scenes are still excellent and there is choreography in every move but the film is too long and the plot is too complicated while not interesting. The comedy scenes are too stupid to be fun. Jackie Chan is unquestionably a master in action scenes, they are innovative, well written and well shot.

The film starts just after the first part where Jackie Chan‚Äôs character has to take responsibility for all the collateral damages he has done. But it quickly go back to normal and he will do more cop stuff. The film is generous in type of sequences and number of supporting characters but it‚Äôs just too lengthy to keep a good pace. Fun but less than the first Police Story.

Urgences

by Raymond Depardon


My first film from Depardon, while he‚Äôs a great French documentary filmmaker, I was mistaken him with Pierre Carles, to show my lacking culture about French documentaries.

It‚Äôs moving, it‚Äôs stranger than fiction. I got connected with people in a few minutes and was afraid for their future. It‚Äôs terribly sad to see some lost spirits like this.

The beginning was a bit slow and dry but, quickly, it presents really touching characters, the edit and directing can‚Äôt be more humble, the film only consists of long fixed shots that only move to follow the hectic movements of some patients. I love this system, it‚Äôs simple, states clearly from the beginning that they all agree to be filmed. I don‚Äôt have second thoughts on the making, like on The Vow, the HBO documentary about NXIVM cult, that I just finished watching the first season. It‚Äôs the opposite, no extra footage, no cliffhanger or any dishonest methods.

It‚Äôs covering a large spectrum of mental disease, light to severe, and all characters are iconic, it‚Äôs down-to-earth but incredible at the same time.

Fin
